Award.AwardTitle: Conjugated Hybrids: Functionalization of Polyaromatic and Pi-Conjugated Systems with Group 13 Elements
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Professor Frieder Jaekle develops new conjugated hybrid materials that contain electron-deficient Group 13 elements (boron, aluminum, gallium, and indium). Conjugated organic materials enjoy ubiquitous applications in organic electronics, sensory materials, and supramolecular chemistry. This research aims to take advantage of recent advances in the field of Main Group Chemistry for the development of new types of conjugated hybrid materials. Organoborane groups offer electron-acceptor effect that are useful in new solution-processible materials for light emitting devices (LEDs), field-effect transistors (FETs), and photovoltaics (OPVs) - applications where acceptor materials remain in high demand. In addition, Lewis acidic organoboranes show promise as sensors for anions and other toxic small molecules.

Selective boron-silicon and boron-tin exchange chemistries, Lewis base-directed electrophilic aromatic substitutions, and strategies for borenium cation formation are exploited to prepare new classes of pi-conjugated materials that are expected to exhibit: (i) strong electron-acceptor character, (ii) charge transfer and two-photon absorption properties, and (iii) a propensity for assembly on surfaces or interaction with other carbon nanomaterials. The project contributes to the training of a diverse group of students in an interdisciplinary research environment. A special focus is placed on the training of students from groups underrepresented in chemistry (e.g. American Chemical Society Project SEED high school students). Students benefit from collaborations with physical chemists in the US and Germany. In addition, Professor Jaekle organizes symposia and conferences such as the annual "Boron in the Americas" meeting.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at generating innovative hybrid materials by functionalizing π-conjugated (poly)aromatic species with Group 13 elements. In one such approach we explored the synthesis of boron-functionalized π-conjugated oligomers and macrocycles. New types of bora-cyclophanes with tailored properties such as superior electron-accepting character, enhanced intramolecular charge transfer (ICT) behavior, and an improved tendency for assembly on surfaces were targeted. Oligomers that combine electron-deficient arylboranes with organic electron-acceptors were also investigated, yielding new insights into the electronic structure, redox behavior, and anion binding properties of these rare examples of boron-based acceptor-π-acceptor materials. In a second approach, the peripheral functionalization of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) with B-N moieties has been pursued. In addition to developing efficient synthetic routes we also explored the structure-property relationships. Electrochemical and photophysical measurements were supported by computational studies, offering detailed insights into the fundamental effects of B-N functionalization. In collaborative research, selected compounds were tested in field effect transistor and organic photovoltaic devices.

The project enabled the training of 1 postdoctoral researcher, 4 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students. In addition, 3 high school students were provided with an opportunity to participate in the research program over the summer months. The program was enriched by collaborative efforts with researchers in the US, Germany, China and Japan, including a research visit of a graduate student from Japan to our labs.

Serving the broader scientific community, the PI co-organized a 2-day research symposium on “Non-conventional Building Blocks in Conjugated Materials” at the 2017 Fall ACS National Meeting while also coediting a book on “Main Group Strategies towards Functional Hybrid Materials”, which is expected to serve as general reference for those interested to learn more about this exciting field. In terms of local outreach efforts, the PI organized and participated in several high school visits to Rutgers University. In total about 100 students, many of them from minority-serving schools, had an opportunity to experience current research efforts in materials chemistry first hand, while also learning about college applications, curricula, and opportunities for support.

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2017
Modified by: Frieder Jaekle
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project was aimed at generating innovative hybrid materials by functionalizing π-conjugated (poly)aromatic species with Group 13 elements. In one such approach we explored the synthesis of boron-functionalized π-conjugated oligomers and macrocycles. New types of bora-cyclophanes with tailored properties such as superior electron-accepting character, enhanced intramolecular charge transfer (ICT) behavior, and an improved tendency for assembly on surfaces were targeted. Oligomers that combine electron-deficient arylboranes with organic electron-acceptors were also investigated, yielding new insights into the electronic structure, redox behavior, and anion binding properties of these rare examples of boron-based acceptor-π-acceptor materials. In a second approach, the peripheral functionalization of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) with B-N moieties has been pursued. In addition to developing efficient synthetic routes we also explored the structure-property relationships. Electrochemical and photophysical measurements were supported by computational studies, offering detailed insights into the fundamental effects of B-N functionalization. In collaborative research, selected compounds were tested in field effect transistor and organic photovoltaic devices. The project enabled the training of 1 postdoctoral researcher, 4 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students. In addition, 3 high school students were provided with an opportunity to participate in the research program over the summer months. The program was enriched by collaborative efforts with researchers in the US, Germany, China and Japan, including a research visit of a graduate student from Japan to our labs. Serving the broader scientific community, the PI co-organized a 2-day research symposium on "Non-conventional Building Blocks in Conjugated Materials" at the 2017 Fall ACS National Meeting while also coediting a book on "Main Group Strategies towards Functional Hybrid Materials", which is expected to serve as general reference for those interested to learn more about this exciting field. In terms of local outreach efforts, the PI organized and participated in several high school visits to Rutgers University. In total about 100 students, many of them from minority-serving schools, had an opportunity to experience current research efforts in materials chemistry first hand, while also learning about college applications, curricula, and opportunities for support.
